text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 11.3.30, Disclosure of Official Information, Disclosure to the President.
Editorial changes have been made throughout to update IRM/statute/organizational references, to correct outdated links or improve clarity.
Added new (3) to IRM 11.3.30.3, Processing Requests, to capture the accounting requirements for disclosures made under IRC section 6103(g)(1).
This supersedes IRM 11.3.30 dated February 15, 2017.

) Purpose: This IRM section provides instructions concerning the returns and return information to the President or speciﬁed White House Scope employees pursuant to IRC §
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees and (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (
) Program Owner: The GLDS office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the vicewide Disclosure policy. (

) Primary Stakeholders: The following offices have the responsibility for sures to the President: • Office of the Commissioner • Office of the Deputy Commissioner, Services and Enforcement (in absence of the Commissioner) (

) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section is applicable for the Office of Commissioner, Office of the Deputy Commissioner Services and and as well as the Office of Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and (GLDS). This IRM is also used by all IRS employees to help comply with disclosure provisions of IRC §
) pertaining to disclosures to the President. (
) The following is a list of the terms and acronyms that are used in this section:
Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy.

Terms and Deﬁnitions Term Deﬁnition Joint Committee on Taxation Congressional Advisory committee charged with monitor- ing federal tax policy and estimating the impact of proposed changes to tax policy Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition GLDS Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards IRC Internal Revenue Code IRM Internal Revenue Manual PGLD Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure USC United States Code
) Returns or return information may be provided to the President only upon written request signed by the President. (

) Such requests shall include: a. The name and address of the taxpayer whose return or return tion is to be disclosed; b. The kind of return and return information which is to be disclosed; c. The taxable period or periods covered by such return or return tion; and d. The speciﬁc reason why the inspection or disclosure is requested. (

) The President may designate, by name, a White House employee or employees to receive tax information. Disclosure of tax information shall made to any employee whose annual rate of basic pay is less than the rate of basic pay speciﬁed by section
of Title
, of the United States Code (USC). Note: The designated employees may not disclose tax information to any other person except the President without the personal written direction of the President. (
) Only the Commissioner, or in the absence of the Commissioner, the Commissioner, Services & Enforcement, will make returns or return available to the President. (
) Should any IRS employee receive a Presidential request for returns or information, such request should be promptly forwarded to the Chief

) Only the Commissioner, or in the absence of the Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner, Services & Enforcement, will make returns or return information available to the President.
Should any IRS employee receive a Presidential request for returns or return information, such request should be promptly forwarded to the Chief Privacy
Officer, Office of Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD), through the head of the employee’s office. (
) Disclosures to the President under IRC §
) will require disclosure counting under IRC §
). See IRM
, Recordkeeping and Accounting for Disclosures. (
) The President is required to ﬁle a report with the Joint Committee on within

days after the close of each calendar quarter. The report will set forth: a. The names of taxpayers with respect to whom requests were made during the quarter; b. The returns or return information involved; and c. The reasons for the requests. (
) The President will not be required to report on requests for returns or return information pertaining to an individual who was an employee of the Branch at the time the request was made. (

) The reports shall not be disclosed unless the Joint Committee on Taxation termines that disclosure of the reports (or parts of the report) including identifying details would be in the national interest. (
) Reports shall be maintained by the Joint Committee on Taxation for a period not exceeding
years unless, within such period, it is determined that a sure to Congress is necessary.
The President is required to ﬁle a report with the Joint Committee on Taxation within 30 days after the close of each calendar quarter. The report will set
